Thou fancy's legitimate son,</br>Description's most favourite child,</br>Immortal's the wreath thou hast won</br>From subjects terrific and mild;</br>When spring with her rose-sprinkl'd crown,</br>Or summer with chaplets of green,</br>Brown autumn pour'd plenty around,</br>Or winter invested the scene.

O Thomson, like thee could she soar,</br>The muse to depaint might aspire,</br>Melodious, the seasons deplore,</br>Or wake to her sorrows the lyre.</br>Denied thy progression to fame,</br>Be venial her flight as resign'd,</br>Unhallow'd, if rises the flame,</br>Uncherish'd by bards more refin'd.

Does Janus erect the young year,</br>What terror await on its birth!</br>In varied solemnity rear</br>Aquarius, to govern the earth,</br>In cincture of sable the storm</br>The breast with opacity shrouds,</br>Its quietude can it deform,</br>When virtue resisteth it clouds?

The mind self-collected shall stand,</br>Unshaken by tempest or gloom,</br>Integrity stretches her hand,</br>Secures to contentment her bloom;</br>Lysander then droop not my friend,</br>Nor sigh o'er the waste of the day,</br>Let winter her tyrannies send,</br>Thy heart shall still mantle with May.

The snow than thy morals less white,</br>A landscape unusual affords,</br>Involves the high mountains in night,</br>Insensibly scatters its hoards;</br>Indulg'd for a moment I pass,</br>Comparison humble to make,</br>What wealth the pale misers amass</br>Augments like the snow on the brake.

Or as thro' the crevice its fleece</br>Grows silently up to a heap;</br>The wretch eyes his splendid increase,</br>Which robs his sad vigils of sleep;</br>The simile farther extends,</br>His glass of mortality run,</br>His piles some young prodigal sends,</br>Which sink as the snow in the sun.

While sighs the sharp wind in the rock,</br>What sound do I hear from the fane?</br>Methinks 'tis the frozen-tongu'd clock,</br>Slow mutters the time to the plain.</br>Ah!  no to my terror-struck ear,</br>Thy knell 'tis Amanda that peals,</br>What cheek is exempt from a tear,</br>What heart not of marble but feels.

As beauteous as spring, when she rear'd</br>Her locks vi'let-woven with bloom,</br>Amanda to Friendship appear'd,</br>As beauteous sunk down to the tomb;</br>Her hand was necessity's guard,</br>Supported the children of woe,</br>Could wishes her sentence retard,</br>The eyes of the muse would not flow.

But hark!  'tis the eddies that roar,</br>Thro' Medway as circling they fly,</br>Snow-fed from the pondering shore,</br>Ah no, 'tis the villages sigh,</br>O death!  not a current more pure,</br>Didst thou ever impede in its course,</br>Cou'd woman thy terrors allure,</br>Thy dart must have lost all its force.

The genius of snow from the north,</br>In mantle of brilliancy dress'd,</br>I shudder to see him come forth,</br>And lord o'er the country distress'd;</br>The nymphs of the vallies and groves,</br>Affrighted abscond from his pow'r,</br>O!  name not the graces and loves,</br>They hide from the envious show'r.

Lo mountains on mountains arise,</br>A splendid tho' terrible weight;</br>Sure Zembla has shifted her skies,</br>Or Rhodope sent us her freight.</br>From Zembla's unciviliz'd coast,</br>Admit, that the genius of woe,</br>Forth issues a numberless host,</br>An army mail-coated with snow.

Shall winter on whose icy car</br>Congenial rigours await,</br>The morning and evening star</br>Illumine to beam on her state?</br>Shall frost forge his strong silver chains,</br>In bandage wild nature to hold,</br>A tyrant rule over the plains,</br>Exclude from their pasture the fold.

Then come my Lysander if rhime,</br>Uncouth and grotesque as the day</br>Can furnish amusement to time,</br>Let fancy replenish the lay.</br>To her soft seduction we yield,</br>And blame not the innocent cheat,</br>Be all her wild portraits reveal'd,</br>With novelties ever replete.

O'er all the white waves let her rove,</br>Creations illusive to view,</br>Descend full of sport from her grove,</br>Enchantments around us to strew;</br>Permit us gay pow'r to attend,</br>Inspecting each whimsical scene,</br>Which thou fond magician shalt lend,</br>Romantic, antique, or serene.

The shallow of yonder vast drift,</br>Lysander, come let us explore,</br>Her tube fancy grants that we lift,</br>Extend all thy critical lore;</br>But here see the chissel of art,</br>A passage has cleft in the snow,</br>Whilst gems their bright sparkles impart,</br>A journey subnivial we go.

See high on yon shed, passing strange,</br>There perches, or seems perch'd, a fowl</br>The poet might call it thy change,</br>Nyctymene turn'd to an owl;</br>Here Pillars, pilasters are seen,</br>An edifice lofty and grand,</br>Columns shatter'd, with portals between,</br>In ruins fall over the land.

There figures half-buried appear,</br>Hieroglyphical monsters arise;</br>A lion or crocodile there,</br>A camel here prostrated lies.</br>Still wave plastic fancy thy wand,</br>Of tombs, and of rocks, let me sing,</br>Of Jupiter turn'd to a swan,</br>For fiction's creative of wing.

Enough of similitude's scenes,</br>To frolicsome fancy adieu!</br>For pity her senate convenes,</br>The anguish of nature to view;</br>She points to the snow-buried cot,</br>Humanity catches her flame:</br>Enlivens the comfortless spot,</br>And calls up to charity fame.

In mantle as white as the snow,</br>Religion is seen in her train,</br>In search of contemporal woe,</br>Christianity measures the plain;</br>Hail first-born of heaven, whose charm</br>Despondency causes to smile,</br>Where blessings the season can warm,</br>And cherish the offspring of toil.

O charity!  born of the skies,</br>The hymn of contentment receive,</br>From gratitude hear it arise,</br>To thee ever prone to relieve,</br>Affliction who late in the vale</br>The fears of anxiety shed,</br>Whose infants thro' hunger were pale,</br>Acknowledges whence they were fed.

Blest isle whose rich bounty appears,</br>To yield the unhappy their part,</br>To wipe sorrow's cheeks, stain'd with tears,</br>When poverty harrows the heart,</br>Enlarged the sensations of those,</br>Like cherubs of heavenly light,</br>Who shorten the season of woes</br>Epitomize poverty's night.

Benevolence, blessing divine,</br>Fair native, down-wing'd from above,</br>The task of sweet sympathy's thine,</br>The task of affection and love,</br>To lift up the sad pensive eye,</br>To pour the soft balm upon woe,</br>Bid indigence banish her sigh,</br>And kind hospitality flow.

Ye herds who frequent the rude stall,</br>Ye folds that in flocks croud the pen,</br>O start not at nature's white pall,</br>Nor shudder ye fowls of the fen,</br>The sun from the south shall unbind,</br>The menacing fetters of frost,</br>The snow shall dissolve in the wind,</br>Her empire be conquer'd and lost.

New beauties shall open the year,</br>These terrible scenes supercede,</br>Young spring in gay mantle appear,</br>Soft pleasure determine the lead;</br>The mazes which curl from the glade,</br>Where now desolations renew,</br>Delightful shall lengthen a shade,</br>And add to each beautiful view.

In mantle of velvet the grove,</br>Soft zephyrs shall murmuring fan</br>The choristers warble of love,</br>Pure bliss the perfection of man!</br>The God of each season to praise,</br>Let numbers incessantly flow,</br>'Tis his winter's triumphs to raise,</br>Whose goodness emaciates the snow.</br>
